concern:
I’m currently taking a hybrid class and the professor does not allow any outside help with test, so no book, internet, etc. and states that if you leave the screen during an exam, he will consider it cheating. It is also timed. 

I had a midterm due yesterday and took after a different night class, so I’m taking this test at like 10:30 at night on my iPad. My kid isn’t feeling the hottest so I’m also cuddling and tending to him while taking this test (we are a military family with no family around us so no, no one else could watch my kid at 10:30 at night). I’m half way through my test when the low battery notification pops up in the middle of my screen and now I’m freaking out that it will look like I “got out of the test screen” because of this. 

Does anyone know if that will log it in canvas as “left screen”? It was there for like maybe 30ish seconds) I feel silly for stressing this much over it, but I can’t afford to fail a midterm, especially over a low battery warning.

dialogue_total.statement: Welcome! It's great to have you here. Is there anything you'd like to talk about today?
I'm glad to be here. I've been feeling really stressed about managing my schoolwork and family responsibilities, and I'd like to talk about some strategies to handle that anxiety.
That sounds like a lot to juggle. It's understandable that you're feeling stressed. Can you tell me more about what your schoolwork and family responsibilities look like right now?

My schoolwork involves taking online classes with strict exam rules that add to my pressure, making it hard to focus. As a military family without nearby support, my family responsibilities include caring for my child, especially when he's unwell, which often overlaps with my study time and heightens my anxiety.

It sounds like you have a lot on your plate, balancing your online classes and caring for your child without much external support. That would be challenging for anyone. It's no wonder you're feeling anxious. How do you typically handle stress and anxiety when it starts to build up?

I usually try to take a few deep breaths and step away briefly to check on my child, which helps me refocus amid the chaos. However, when the anxiety builds from my school demands overlapping with family needs, it often feels overwhelming and hard to shake off on my own.

It's great that you have some coping strategies in place already, like taking deep breaths and checking on your child. It sounds like these strategies help you stay grounded in the moment, but they might not be enough when anxiety builds up from multiple sources. In situations like that, have you ever tried reaching out to a friend, family member, or even a classmate for support?

I've occasionally reached out to classmates for quick study tips, but it hasn't helped much with my overall anxiety since our military lifestyle means we lack local family or friends for reliable support. As a result, I often end up managing everything alone, which amplifies the stress from juggling school and family demands.

That must be really tough, feeling like you're all on your own with these big responsibilities. It's no wonder that your anxiety can feel overwhelming. Have you considered looking into any online support groups or counseling services specifically for military families or students? These could provide you with a sense of community and understanding, even if you don't have local support.

Yes, I've looked into online support groups for military families and counseling services through the school, as they seem like valuable resources for connecting with others in similar situations. I'm hoping they can offer more effective ways to manage my anxiety from balancing school demands and family responsibilities.

It's great that you're open to exploring these resources. Online support groups and counseling services can definitely provide a sense of community and understanding, and they may offer additional coping strategies that you haven't considered before. It might also be helpful to set aside specific times for selfcare, even if it's just a few minutes a day to do something that brings you joy or relaxation. Have you found any selfcare activities that work well for you?

I find that simple activities like taking a short walk or listening to calming music help me unwind and reduce my anxiety, even amidst my busy schedule. However, with the constant overlap of school pressures and family duties, I sometimes struggle to make time for them consistently, which makes my overall stress harder to manage.

It's wonderful that you recognize the importance of selfcare activities like walking and listening to music. Consistency can be challenging, but perhaps we can brainstorm ways to make these activities more accessible, even in small doses, to help manage your anxiety. For example, could you try listening to calming music while you're studying or taking care of your child?

I think listening to calming music while studying or caring for my child could be a practical way to incorporate selfcare without disrupting my routine, as it helps me stay relaxed amid the overlapping demands. However, I sometimes worry that even small distractions might affect my focus on schoolwork, making it tricky to balance everything effectively.

That's a valid concern. Perhaps we can find a compromise, like playing the music at a low volume or using instrumental tracks without lyrics. This way, you can still benefit from the calming effects of music without sacrificing your focus on schoolwork. Have you tried anything like this before?

I haven't tried playing music at a low volume or using instrumental tracks before, though I've experimented with general background music to stay calm. I'm concerned that even subtle distractions could heighten my anxiety when balancing school demands with family care.

Your worries are understandable, given the delicate balance you're trying to maintain. Perhaps we can explore other sensory tools, like using a stress ball or fidget toy to keep your hands busy while studying. These tools can provide a calming outlet without adding auditory distractions. Have you ever tried using sensory tools for stress relief?

I've experimented with simple stress relief methods like deep breathing, but I haven't specifically tried sensory tools like stress balls or fidget toys. I'm interested in exploring them if they can help manage my anxiety without adding more complications to balancing my school and family responsibilities.

It sounds like you're open to trying new stress relief techniques, which is great! Using sensory tools like stress balls or fidget toys can be a simple yet effective way to release tension and stay focused. Plus, they're discreet, so you can use them while studying or taking care of your child without causing any disruptions. Are you willing to give them a try?

Yes, I'm willing to give sensory tools like stress balls a try to help manage my anxiety. I believe they could provide a subtle way to handle the ongoing stress from balancing my school demands and family responsibilities.

Great! I'm glad you're open to exploring new ways to manage your anxiety. Remember, it's important to be patient with yourself as you try out these tools. It might take some time to find what works best for you, but you're on the right track by seeking out support and experimenting with different techniques. You've got this!

Thank you for your encouragement it really helps to know I'm on the right path. I'll make an effort to be patient with these new tools as I work through the ongoing stress of balancing my responsibilities.
